text:
WASHINGTON, July 23.—Recent hints by Republican leaders that President Roosevelt should be impeached started a flood of political speeches in the House today. Representative Fish, Republican, of New York, added to the Democratic feeling with a declaration that it would be foolish to impeach the President for acts for which the House, the Speaker and the Democratic leaders were "doubly to blame."

"The Democratic majority of this House has surrendered the constitutional power of the House and turned it over to the autocrat in the White House," Mr. Fish said.

"The issue in 1936 will be the restoration of representative, constitutional government in the United States.

"The President has usurped the powers of Congress and it is time we called a halt."

Representatives Warren of North Carolina, Rich of Pennsylvania and McCormack of Massachusetts joined in the oratory, which followed a statement by Mr. Fish yesterday after the assertion by Representative Snell of New York, the Republican leader, that Mr. Roosevelt had trod "perilously close" to impeachable grounds.
authors: Special To The New York Times.
title: IMPEACHMENT HINT STIRS HOUSE CLASH; Democratic Orators Spring to Roosevelt Defense, Charging 'Malice.'

meta_data.description: Repr Fish and other Repubs attack Roosevelt, in House, for usurping Cong powers; impeachment hinted; Dems defend Pres
